page.title: 02ALL SAINTS' CHURCH
page.content:
The church in Croughton is thought to have been first built soon after the first Domesday survey, and consecrated about 1080. Changes took place over the centuries, and currently time and effort is being expended in fund raising for restoration. The first part of the restoration programme was completed in 1983, and a second campaign is underway, with work to begin after Easter 86.
A particular feature of the church is the {wall paintings}, probably painted between 1280 and 1300, and consequently plastered over at the Reformation. Re-discovered in 1921, they are in dire need of conservation. They are important to the history of English art, particularly for the completeness of the story cycles of the life of Christ and the Virgin.
